pros: Good working hours and work environment.
cons: Management are lacking communication skill and outlining what is expected from staff.

review_title: Morale is quite low and work culture is poor.
pros: I have met wonderful people here who have become very good friends of mine and I thoroughly enjoy working with my colleagues. The campus is small, but lovely, and most people are very friendly. It is often 'a home away from home'.
cons:
HR is run very poorly. Some HR reps have very cavalier attitudes and believe that rules and laws don't apply to them. Unfortunately this is no surprise as they have been able to get away with very questionable practices with little or no consequences and/or oversight from their direct superiors. Furthermore, some HR reps seem far more interested in supporting managerial staff than those in what some may regard as 'normal' roles. This has led to mistrust among some staff members who believe they will not be treated fairly and justly. There is a general fear that if a staff member complains about mistreatment from their superiors that they will be 'black listed' and this may affect job security. This has inevitably led to the declining morale and mental wellbeing of staff and a very poor work culture. There is also very little support for disabled staff as no expert training is offered to raise disability awareness among managerial staff. 

That said, all hope is not lost as I believe this could be overcome with more support and oversight from the senior leadership team and the hiring of individuals with high moral character to lead on a much needed cultural shift and overhaul. SLT have become too complacent in their treatment of their employees, and nepotism is rife within higher circles, and this needs to be addressed.

pros: Lovely colleagues who became great friends. A commendable vision, misson and ambitions. I really wanted to stay to contribute to this relatively small university achieving its ambitions, but chose to leave due to 'cons' below.
cons: Unfortunately, the organisation does not have a suitable structure and the right key people to achieve its ambitions. Specifically some middle- mid-senior managers are not properly trained or experienced. They should not be allowed the responsibility of line managing staff, and the duty of care that involves. Some are allowed to get away with bullying those they manage and also undermine others for their own advancement (taking credit for others work, demoting people without good reason, constructive dismissal, empty promises of promotion and progression, lies). Those who claimed to be committed to EDI planned recruitment around getting staff (often over qualified) on the cheap. I left feeling so disheartened as I really wanted to be part of the CCCU community and contribute to its inspiring vision and mission.

pros: Nice colleagues who really care about students
cons: Appalling communication from management, no integrated working across the university. Slow to react, no pro activity in addressing issues. Bullying. Learning and development only available for the few.

pros: Great laid back atmosphere Good People
cons: Wages could be better for staff

pros: The company has flexible working.
cons: Sometimes when you answer the phone to students they can be rude but it's nothing compared to if you've ever worked in retail.

pros: Mostly friendly staff who mean well.
cons: No opportunities for a research career whatsoever. Culture of staff taking roles/hours and doing nothing even when it negatively impacts careers of colleagues. Overwork on popular undergraduate degrees due to over-enrolment of students through clearing and lack of resourcing. Lack of incentives to do anything other than the bare minimum of your teaching workload.

pros: There is absolutely nothing positive to say!
cons: They will hire anyone, even if that person has not yet finished their PhD. This means that you are surrounded by inexperience, and you really feel it. The turnover at this university is ridiculous. Every year they are hiring because people leave in drones. There is absolutely no respect for past experience. Research in some schools is your responsibility; there is no help getting one started, unless they are bootlicking the boss(es). The salary is terrible. Postdocs at other universities get paid more than lecturers here. Pay wouldn't be such an issue if Canterbury itself was not so VERY expensive. The bosses all live in areas other than Canterbury because of this, but you are expected to find shared accommodation to make ends meet. Sucking up to management guarantees promotion, otherwise you are basically ignored. Bullying is standard practice, despite their motto being "respect". Due to this place my mental health was declining, but luckily I got out before it got too bad. If you value research and education more than titles and appearances, then stay away from this "university".

pros: flexible hours when student ambassador
cons: training sometimes wasn't needed or convenient for my schedule

pros:
- Interesting Job
- Nice team
cons:
- Absolutely zero actual training program: my training consisted of looking over ends sheets of paper and talking through systems verbally with my manager, and then being thrown into an exam board where nobody explained anything to me. I was given nothing to do on the daily, despite me asking team members if there was anything I could help them with so much that I got sick of doing so. The response almost every time was 'no.' 

Zero Opportunities to even do your job - and then criticised for it: When lockdown happened, any small amount of "training" (see above and below for a description of what this non-existent "training" was), everything stopped. I felt forgotten, and every time I emailed around to ask about things that I could do I was told there was nothing. I was left responding to emails, though this frequently involved asking others for key information on processes..... Because I'd had no training. I was basically ignored and sidelined for 6 months.

I was then essentially asked to leave before I was fired for not doing my job..... Even though there was no way for me to do my job. After a YEAR of working, I was sitll being told there were things I couldn't do because I hadn't been trained, but when I raised this to my manager I was told that I had been trained (presumably because it was one of the things the manager verbally rambled at me about in our small handful of non-interactive verbal sessions). 

Appalling.

pros: normally have leave over christmas when the university closes, some good benifits and perks working with the university
cons: Management are lacking direction, promotes people into roles they are not always ready for and doesnt support them afterwards. Not easy to take leave when you want it and not a good work/life balance. Pay is below average for the market

pros:

review_title: A progressive and lovely place to work
job_title: Director of Technical Services in Canterbury, England
pros:
It is a people centred place to work.
My voice is listened to.
Teams work together to make things happen.
cons: Communication falls down and people don't know what is going on.

pros: Nice people around campus. The staff that actually do the work are lovely people
cons:
The university has a culture of both bullying and deceit. Some fairly horrible and distressing incidents have taken place at the university but brushed under the carpet and those involved paid off. Too many layers on over paid management both senior and middle that take place in institutionally wide bullying. Managers are often promoted to roles they are not capable of doing without at interview progress whilst lower staff are made to routinely interview for their own jobs in flawed restructures. Transparency is not a thing here.

Avoid taking a job here you will regret it - you have been warned

review_title: Poor management lets down staffs and student
pros: Good canteen food and prices
cons: Poor management reacts to crises rather than leading through clearly defined strategy.

pros: Pleasant campus, pension and holidays are reasonably good
cons:
A very disorganised and chaotic environment, where some work very hard and others do as little as possible in terms of productivity, which is extremely frustrating. Hence there is always a backlog of work in every department and some tasks simply remain unfinished. Not all staff are welcoming and helpful, in fact some are borderline rude.

Senior and middle management make illogical decisions and seem to have little concern for the ramifications of those decisions, and the effect they have on staff, students and the university as a whole. 

In conclusion, avoid if you can.

review_title: Makes a huge difference to young people's lives
pros: IntoUniversity puts young people at the centre of all it does. It has an amazing impact in a range of programmes. Particularly transformative is Academic Support, providing physical space for young people to learn to love learning is honestly a privilege to be part of. Early intervention means that young people are invested in long term and if you stay at the organisation, you get to see children transform into adults achieving their goals. Something I will treasure forever. The organisation is very culture and values led and makes decisions with both the young people and the staff in mind. I always felt valued and appreciated. Lots of career progression and options, much more than any other organisation I have worked for, which was partly why I stayed at the organisation for so long. Working with and managing a staff team that care so deeply about making a difference meant management and generally working environment was a pleasure to be a part of.
cons: As a previous teacher as a reference point, the work life balance at IU I have always found really good - I never took work home, I rarely worked additional hours and when I did I knew that I got generous discretionary days. Working with young people can be tiring particularly when you work with young people that come from a vulnerable backgrounds. But being able to do that in a team of 4 or 5 meant that was shared. Safeguarding cases can be emotionally challenging but also unavoidable to make sure the young people are safe from harm. Most of the staff are recruited as new graduates which can mean that they don't see all of the positives of working at IU, this can be frustrating at times when you are someone with more experience.

review_title: Not inclusive of staff with access needs.
pros: - The charity is amazing for the young people and offers support into opportunities they might not otherwise gain access to. - the majority of staff are lovely people who really care about the cause - the team bonding activities within centres and cross centres is great. - it is a place where you gain a lot of transferrable skills very quickly.
cons: - long hours - extra early starts and late finishes but no TOIL system and no overtime pay. - staff expected to carry heavy resources home and to venues. - summer working hours make no sense - there is very little to do but you are asked to work an extra hour a day to finish early on a Friday. - disabled staff have no support. Centres are not wheelchair accessible but the charity is 20 years old. - CEO is not in touch with staff on the frontline and senior leadership team on the whole are quite condescending and un -empathetic. - Staff have very little creative license as the system is very rigid and the IU way is the only way. - Pay is far too low considering workload - no work-life balance.

review_title: Very rewarding work at the price of your physical/mental health
pros: I was incredibly lucky with the team I worked with and couldn't have asked for better support within my centre. The kids were inspiring, you form close relationships with them and it was great to get to know the community around my centre. Your confidence and skillset grow massively at IntoUni as you are thrown into the deep end. Academic support, Primary FOCUS and post-16 workshops are useful for the students and make a real impact. Despite all the negatives, I would recommend working as an education worker as it is very rewarding, although it is not sustainable in the long term.
cons: Really depends on the centre on your experience. Senior management not willing to let you work from home even if there are no programmes on - it felt like one rule for them and another for everyone else. I felt genuinely exhausted towards the end of the week due to the commute and the physical intensity of the job. As an able bodied person it was challenging, let alone if you have any disabilities which contradicted their D&I ethos. Senior management should allow more than one wfh day a month for the sake of retaining their staff. We were told off for having one day off a month but senior management because it was in our probation period (6 months), which they backtracked on as they didn't know their own policies. I commuted over an hour to work mostly so my working day door to door could be 7.45am - 7.15pm. During the training period senior management did not seem to take into account where people are living and did not explain the thought process behind sending you to a centre an hour away from where you live, despite there being 4 much closer. There was also no official TOIL policy and depended on your centre leader. Centre leaders are definitely overworked. There was not enough time to brief properly for programmes which were often delivered at a poor standard. The second focus programmes are outdated and not useful for the students. No real chance for progression - the senior education worker position seems like a strategy retain staff but based on nothing. There are no real extra responsibilities and there is no progression up from there (other than centre leader which seems like a very stressful and underpaid job). You were expected to cover programmes which were miles away at the drop of a hat, which would be difficult given the exhaustion. Why can't senior management help to cover? Everything falls apart when a staff member is sick or on leave.

review_title: Learn new skills but extremely poor work/life balance
job_title: Senior Education Worker in London, England
pros: - learn excellent transferable skills - work with great staff - I was lucky enough to have a great manager, however I've heard horror stories across the network of poor management. - children are wonderful and a joy to work with - get to fully take responsibility over your strand and manage it how you like
cons: - very very poor work life balance. Often come into work for 8:30 (an hour before you're contracted to start) and leave at 6pm. There is no TOIL policy in place. - values quality but doesn't give the staff any time to implement quality. Everything is so rushed and so frequently understaffed that quality of provision tends to slip. There is not enough time in the day to complete all of the tasks you need to do. - things fall apart if someone is on AL or sick. - unsafe ratios for young people when AS is run on 2 people. - culture of 'get on with it' with zero support from Senior Leadership - very limited progression beyond Senior Education Worker - given very random extra responsibilities that don't utilise staff experience and knowledge - very very tiring, delivering programmes almost every single day. No energy to do anything after work

pros: It's flexible, you can meet as often or little (at least 1x a month). Great for when you have exams and you need to step back. My mentee was very receptive and eager to work, so we had productive sessions and we got to know each other well. Those in charge of the centre had great communication with the students and the mentees - I always felt like I could ask them questions etc. I've pulled on the experience a lot in applications in terms of leadership, relationship building and collaboration. It was overall a great experience and I'd highly recommend.
cons: Overall I loved the experience, thank you!

review_title: Committed to helping young people at the expense of staff wellbeing
pros: -All positives in outcome must be weighed against negative experience of working in the charity -Filter Glassdoor reviews by 'full-time' to see the real score without inflation from volunteers -Centre-based model gives uplift in heart of disadvantaged communities around England and Scotland -Much of the programme hits objectives -Academic Support's primary curriculum and secondary provision provide long-term academic and pastoral support -Flagship Year 5 'What is a University' and Year 6 'FOCUS Week' programmes are well conceived and serve as positive introduction to the concept of university -Post-16 provision of Secondary FOCUS offers timely support to students which partner schools may not have the resources to provide -The charity can sell its programme well. Recent efforts to provide quantitative and qualitative data on outcomes of programmes convinces Universities and other funders to invest in IntoUniversity -The breadth of workload allows workers to learn large variety of skills, although without much depth -Role of Centre Leader and above, despite these opportunities being extremely limited, allow you to liaise and learn from stakeholders such as PVCs of universities, heads of schools and various charitable/corporate partners
cons: -Terrible Work-Life balance -Long working hours erode morale over time -Salary of 32k for centre leader is very low for the responsibility, stress and workload -All salaries are low compared to rest of the sector -No proper TOIL policy despite many early starts, curtailed lunches, and late finishes past 6pm -Centre-based model means your experience will be defined by your Centre Leader. If they are part of the 'clique' and do not push back against whims of Head Office then you will be particularly overworked -Instances of bullying from line managers to other staff. Centre-based model consolidates power to the Centre Leader -Regional staff feel that Head Office are very far removed from daily centre life. 'Us vs. them' attitude prevails -Huge workload. Relentless schedule of workshops does not allow any time for quality to be a focus, despite it being one of the corporate buzzwords of the charity -Illness or AL in your team has negative impact on centre operation. Centre operation falls apart with less than 3 staff -Extremely high staff turnover in recent years. Literally 1/3 of workforce leaving at once. This has huge impact on the centre and wellbeing of staff, as well as the young people -High levels of stress and responsibility even at level of Education Worker. Being a Centre Leader and having to manage young, inexperienced and frequently changing team is very difficult -Very limited opportunities for genuine promotion. Education Worker to Senior Education Worker is guaranteed and essentially there to show progression on your CV. Anything above this is very competitive and only comes about when other staff leave -Year 7-10 Secondary FOCUS programme feels arbitrary. What authority do 21-year old Humanities graduates have on teaching young people about entrepreneurship? -Only until recently the application process for education workers gave more points for those who attended high-tariff universities. Given the point of the charity, how could this have been in place for such a long time? -HR can be brutal. No leeway given with strict notice periods - depending when you hand your notice in this can be around 3-4 months. This will definitely put off your future employers if you are at the start of your career, despite what HR will tell you. Please keep this in mind before you apply -Charity feels in a transition period between smaller and larger organisation, and is holding on to its old practices despite them not working with its current larger scale. For example frequent cluster and whole team meetings are mostly waste of time and serve to stress out regional staff having to travel to London around train strikes -Cult vibes. Singing songs and doing little drama skits for when the favourites leave the charity. Leaves a bitter taste when you give up so much of your time for the young people -As a Centre Leader I felt like I did not have enough time to reflect, conceive and implement CPD for my team. There is always a hundred fires to be put out and plates to keep spinning - some new idea by Head Office which needs to be implemented, a spreadsheet to be filled in, or logistical issues of the centre -Funder and corporate visits to the centre are organised last-minute with minimal support from Head Office. Attitude of 'deal with it'. -Centres are often dingy and depressing. It takes a toll on mental health in dark winter months finishing at 6pm -Logistics of onboarding and training new Education Workers doesn't make sense. If you start outside of the January/August cohorts, you will receive a very rushed initial training by Centre Leader, then learn everything as you work. However you will still have to attend the full 6 weeks of in-person training with the next cohort in London. It will be redundant and largely a waste of time. Taking away Education Workers in these instances only adds pressure to centre teams -6 weeks of training feels like it could be done in 3. No formal qualifications for this or at any other time in the charity - there used to be external leadership training -The charity's leadership training is full of manifestation nonsense. 'Visualise it and it will come to you'. Philosophy of the already rich and successful -Not much to do for much of the Summer period - often feels pointless being there. Give staff a few weeks off to de-stress and unwind rather than the rigid policy of half-days on Fridays (if you don't take AL) -Cover system in London means you can be needed all over the city. Regional centres often have no cover available - deal with it -All reviews on Glassdoor put location as London to avoid negative feedback being traced back to their actual centre

job_title: Senior Education Worker in Leeds, England
pros:
- you do learn a lot of skills and a lot about Education, so you would be to specialise after the grad scheme 

- you meet and get to know some really nice young people 

- you get to go on some fun trips
cons:
- like other reviews said, working here feels like a cult. There is a sickeningly toxic 'can do' positive attitude that can be found throughout the charity and is forced whenever it's a hard or busy time, which is often. They never actually address or seem to want to solve the cause of the issue though. 

- there are so many issues with how the charity handles issues around D&I. Quite fankly, if you have a disability or from a minority ethnic background then the job will be 10x harder than it already is. From covert to casual culturally offensive comments from new to senior staff and sometimes disguised as 'feedback', and constantly moving tables, going on campus tours and commuting to and from schools, this job isn't for anyone who ticks these boxes. 

- There is a concerningly lack of diversity within the senior management/leadership team which is poor considering the diverse background of students. 

- the charity will say they're doing things to improve D&I but everyone is too overworked to actually acknowledge this behaviour and commit to improving this. Ironically those who need D&I training most are those in Centre Leader roles or above. 

- your experience will very much depend on the centre/cluster youre based in, which is down to luck. There are a few staff members who are known to be hard to work with but you can't complain due to their seniority (no matter how much they say you can, you can't). 

- there is a very high staff turnover and a lot of people leave after 1 year, sometimes even sooner. This means most centres are understaffed or have staff that are still learning the role but are still expected to hit target. This then means most centres are overworked. 

- TOIL isn't recorded accurately enough. The salary might look good on paper but when you break it down, you do a lot more than your contracted hours. The charity makes up for this with 'discretionary days' but its still not enough in my opinion. 

- you have to attend whole team meetings in London 3 times a year but they're mostly a waste of time because everyone is either tired from travelling, in their own friendship group or your friends have already left the charity. You dont really get the chance to meet new people so you have to like your cluster to able to enjoy these meetings. 

- you usually eat lunch with your team which just feels like more work. Also since most centres aren't that diverse, it can be really uncomfortable sitting there but then if you do other stuff, you feel left out of the centres social circle (which is already really small). 

- the only reason why I put 2 stars for career opportunities is for everything you can do once you leave. If you stay in the charity, the promotion you could realistically successfully apply for is Centre Leader. 

- you can raise these issues with whoever you want, however many times you like, communicate this in so many different ways, have as many meetings as your free time allows yet it's very unlikely anything will change (unless you're friends with someone). The issues I have written about have been raised by myself and other before me but nothing was changed no matter how much they say they are 'addressing the issue'. The reviews on here aren't just people complaining about the job but likely people who were so tired of trying to advocate for themselves that it was just easier to leave.

job_title: Lead Senior Education Worker in London, England
pros: - Colleagues were great, met some friends for life. - You get to do cool and very fun things with young people, your friends will envy your job! - Working with the young people and building relationships with families and parents/guardians have left me with some very fond memories - You learn A LOT of transferrable skills which can set you up for a better job in the future. - The first two years of your time you feel challenged and pushed, but this obviously is very dependent on your manager.
cons: - Poorly paid for the amount of work required, and the functions we fulfill for young people. - Little room to advance unless your in the IT crowd, can feel like everyone is climbing over each other for sought after promotions. - Poor line management when you are a senior ed worker or lead senior ed worker. Everyone is just too busy to give you the time of day. - Often felt belittled and treated like a child by SMT, pay your staff better and give more benefits rather than run raffles for john lewis vouchers. - Head office very out of touch with what's happening on the ground. When SMT or SLT come to centres it felt procedural and awkward. Bit of and us vs them vibe. - Restrictive conditions of notice periods and zero flexibility from HR.

review_title: Exploits goodwill of altruistic new grads
job_title: Senior Education Worker in London, England
pros: Good training and support Well structured and organised Attracts fun interesting people - good colleagues
cons: Long days Low pay Creates sense of guilt about being a 'team player' Cult-like work environment Inflexible working patterns

pros: Really good place for professional development in a very friendly team.
cons: Doesn’t have as much opportunity for hybrid working as I would like. One day a week working from home.

job_title: Lead Senior Education Worker in Leeds, England
pros: Learnt a lot. Gave skills i could transfer
cons: Less promotion opportu ities away from london

pros: - the children are great to work with - fellow ed workers were friendly
cons:
- long hours in questionable working conditions (most buildings are falling down and covered in mould) 
- extremely high staff turnover (we are talking about a hundred staff leaving out of three hundred staff network wide a year, the training cohorts see about 80 new employees on their graduate scheme a year without considering those who are hired after the cohort recruitment) without any changes made to ensure employee retention 
- ridiculously low pay 
- felt like working in a cult 
- questionable safeguarding procedures with the outcomes not always best for the child
 - little room for career progression, career opportunities above education worker were senior education worker (one year of service required equalled in an extra £1000 in yearly salary before tax, centre leader at £32,000, dismal pay for the actual requirements of the job)
-really long notice periods required to give when leaving (around 2 months) 
- training extremely long winded (it could've been done over two weeks instead of four) and largely inapplicable to the role and was pedantic and condescending 
- independent thinking strongly discouraged, everything is set out for you leaving no room for things to be done in a more efficient or independent way 
- company 'values' are cult like and are not open to discussion or deliberation, they have to be followed with no room to question the impact or assess the harm that they could inflict. 
- Values are constantly preached yet they are never extended or considered in relation to individual staff needs 
- cold calling was a large part of the job 
- 5 days of the holiday allowance has to be taken at Christmas when the centres close for two weeks or alternatively, unpaid leave
 -CEO is unapproachable whilst claiming to be heavily involved within the charity
- no time in lieu offered for constantly working over agreed hours and short lunch breaks
-minimal amount of staff were aged over 35, most staff were in their early twenties.

pros: Every day is different to the last, charity has good aspirations and outcomes.
cons: Can be very intellectually unstimulating.

pros: Very flexible when organising when I should mentor. Really great community and it's nice to make a difference to a young person's life
cons: There isn't anything noteworthy that is negative

review_title: Fun but long hours - overworked and underpaid
job_title: Lead Senior Education Worker in London, England
pros:
-The children and young people who you work with are amazing - so fun and such resilient young people
-A varied job role, giving you lots of different experience
-Some really fun aspects to the job, you can be really creative
-Able to work with lots of different stakeholders, from schools to universities and corporates
cons:
-Long hours, with lots of early starts, working through lunch breaks and finishing late
-No TOIL policy
-SMT and SLT are so far removed from centre life - have no idea what it is like to work in a busy centre and instead pile on more work
-SMT and SLT do not listen to staff and their concerns 
-Staff morale low, feeling under valued. No wonder so many of the workforce left in Summer 2022

pros: Lots of variety in the job
cons: Long working hours some days

review_title: Lovely place to work with some flaws
pros: - Wonderful children - Really supportive, caring culture, with great benefits - Incredible investment in staff training and development - Really fun to work in small centre teams and there is a genuine investment from management in developing bonds within teams - Allows you to get a flavour of lots of different elements when working with children e.g. safeguarding, delivery and facilitation, community building, resource creation, collaboration with schools etc. - Lots of opportunities for promotion until you reach Centre Leader levels when fewer are available
cons: - Work/ life balance is tricky, especially when cover is required - Slow progress on D+I - Early starts with a TOIL policy that doesn't quite work - Quite heavy load of admin tasks which don't always feel relevant to the role

pros: Great mission and great people
cons: Nothing at all really to say

pros: -Working with young people - it can be a great stepping stone for other opportunities - colleagues make it a lot easier
cons: -the workload is too much, last minute deadlines, quite stressful at times - car drivers not fairly compensated for the use of their own personal vehicle while on the job

review_title: Meaningful, positive and fun place to work
job_title: Lead Senior Education Worker in Nottingham, England
pros:
- Positive and fun place to work
- Genuinely care about the cause they are working to achieve - get to work with a wide range of amazing young people, families, charity partners, community volunteers, schools and staff
- Professional development for staff is a priority
- Every day is different
- Collaborate with stakeholders across the organisation
- Trusted with responsibility and encouraged to develop in leadership
- Supportive, approachable and caring management at all levels in the organisation
cons:
- Fixed working hours 
- For an organisation which heavily promotes professional growth, promotion opportunities can be limited, leading to high staff turn over

review_title: Compassionate and ambitious with room to improve for development opportunities
job_title: Centre Leader in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros:
Staff welfare Skills development Various locations

cons:
Low pay Vs workload
Lack of remote working
London centric

review_title: A rewarding, fun and supportive place to work
job_title: Head Office Staff Member in London, England
pros: Excellent, consistently upheld values of compassion and teamwork. Literally everyone I've met at the charity (180+ people) have been kind and considerate and apply this to their work. Lots of opportunities for growth, training and specialisation in different areas of the charity. Very good working culture and work/life balance - I only ever work late if I want to and have never felt pressure to do so.
cons: Lower pay than you'd expect for the sector, which is saying something given that it's a charity.
